title: Kuma's Law - Plot Divergence Theory
theory: Whenever Bartholomew Kuma appears in the story, the plot will veer off in a wildly divergent direction from what was originally predicted. This theory, coined by a first-time watcher, suggests that Kuma is a narrative catalyst whose appearances fundamentally change the story's trajectory.
author: Never Watched One Piece (Tumblr)

title: Kuma's Teleportation vs Death Theory
theory: When Kuma makes Zoro disappear in Episode 404, the theory emerged that he was teleporting the crew members rather than killing them. Evidence cited includes Moria's dismissive reaction to similar events at Thriller Bark, suggesting these characters survive Kuma's power. The bubble-like effect and Kuma's question about 'vacation destinations' hint at transportation rather than elimination.
author: Never Watched One Piece (Tumblr)

title: Kuma's Revolutionary Army Alliance Theory
theory: Based on Kuma's seemingly helpful actions despite being a Warlord, fans theorized that Kuma secretly supports the Revolutionary Army or harbors hidden grievances against the World Government, possibly related to his own cyborg transformation. His protective actions toward the Straw Hats, despite his position, suggest hidden motives.
author: Community Theory

title: Rayleigh's Intentional Training Setup Theory
theory: Some fans theorized that Rayleigh's appearance in Episode 404, while saving the crew from immediate death, was part of a larger plan to ensure they received proper training. By holding off Kizaru but not defeating him, Rayleigh allowed Kuma to separate the crew to locations where they could grow stronger before attempting the New World.
author: Community Theory

title: Targeted Separation Theory
theory: Fans theorized that Kuma didn't send the Straw Hats to random locations, but specifically chose destinations that would help each crew member grow in ways suited to their abilities and weaknesses. The theory suggested Kuma had detailed knowledge of each crew member's potential and needs.
author: Community Theory
